<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of check_apply_params:
```c
static int
check_apply_params (void)
{
  if (tool_params.help)
  {
    show_help ();
    return -1;
  }
  else if (tool_params.version)
  {
    print_version ();
    return -1;
  }
  check_param_port ();
  check_apply_param__all_cpus ();
  check_apply_param__threads ();
  if (! check_apply_param__thread_per_conn ())
    return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
  if (! check_param__epoll ())
    return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
  if (! check_param__poll ())
    return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
  check_param__empty_tiny_medium_large ();
  check_param__shared_single_unique ();
  if (! check_param__connections ())
    return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
  return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (! check_apply_param__thread_per_conn ())
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.3 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: This fragment does not itself violate Rule 14.3 because the controlling expression calls a function and is therefore not inherently invariant. A violation would occur if check_apply_param__thread_per_conn() were a compile-time constant (for example a macro or an always-true inline that expands to 1), making the expression (!check_apply_param__thread_per_conn()) invariant (always false) — in that specific case the rule would be violated.
